moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 Nd7 4. Bc4: This time Pawnbandit chooses the strongest line against the Hanham Phillidor.
moves.6. Qh5: !? Stronger was 0-0, leading to lines favoring White.
moves.7. Be3 exd4: Now is the time to exchange the pawn.
moves.8. Bxd4 Ne5 9. Bxe5 dxe5 10. Nc3: White still hopes for a brute force attack, but Black has defensive resources.
moves.10... g6 11. Qh4 f6 12. Nf3 Be6: Black wants to exchange off the bishop.
moves.13. Bxe6 Qxe6 14. O-O-O Nf7 15. Rd3 Bd6: At this point, Black decides it is safer to 0-0-0 and block the pressure on the d file.
moves.16. Rhd1 O-O-O 17. Nd2 Be7 18. Nb3 f5: Now is the time to advance the pawns with threat on the Queen.
moves.19. Qg3 f4 20. Qf3 g5 21. Na4 b6: Since the light square bishop has been traded off, Black is more concerned with preventing the Ns from mounting a strong attack.
moves.22. Qe2 Kb7 23. Qd2 Rxd3 24. Qxd3 Rd8 25: After the exchanges, Black wants to continue the expansion on the side opposite the Kings.
moves.27. Qd3 h5 28. c4 Ng5 29. c5: This plan is flawed because Black can advance the pawn and impede the attack.
moves.29... b5 30. Nc3 h4 31. Nxb5: Pawnbandit rightly did not want to sit back and play defensively. I was not expecting the move and had not properly prepared to counter it.
moves.34. Kd2: The critical position. White should have played Qa6+, Kd8 (otherwise mate) QxP. This error gives Black time to consolidate. Today, Pawnbandit would have been all over Black instead.
Now Black can neutralize the attack.
moves.38. Qa5+ Qc7: White has nothing to show for the piece, and resigns.
